history.content:
I think you should be able to count it for upper division requirements, but definitely check with your advisor.

I just took it this semester, and I think 61C and 162 helped a lot. OpenMP is one of the projects (albeit much more involved). Locking and thread management concepts are also discussed. I found that 61C and 162 were indirectly helpful in that a lot of the concepts behind system design were repeated in different contexts (I.e. shared vs distributed memory). Caching is a big theme in the class, and there was a good amount of data structures related content. In general, it featured a potpourri of a lot of systems concepts, so I feel like OS, machine structures, and data structures would definitely be helpful.

Hope this helps! :)

children.subject:
Of course! Not sure regarding pre-reqs, I feel like berkeley historically hasn’t really enforced them. I think as an undergrad u might have to request enrollment, and on the form for undergrads for this semester they did ask about what classes you took in the past.

I think the slides are informative, and it’ll be necessary to review them for the quizzes, but the projects are somewhat difficult and the slides aren’t super helpful. Would highly recommend at least taking 61c since the way it’s taught assumes you understand how basic machine structures work!
Got that. Thank you very much. Can I get your email address? If I have more questions about CS267, can I ask you by email?

Thank you very much for your advice. It helps a lot. I still have two more questions. First, I wonder whether there is a strict prerequisite for CS267. Second, I wonder whether learning the course material by myself is a good way to prepare for this class. I think that I do not have enough time to learn both 61C and CS162 before next spring.

history.content: I am interested in the topic of CS267. I wonder whether it can be used as an upper-division class requirement. What classes I can take to better prepare for this class?
history.subject: The CS Graduate Class CS267
